Why are some monsters gold?
Monster Rancher Metropolis: Monster Rancher Advance 2 Archive (GameBoy Advance): Miscellaneous Q&A (Post New Questions Here): Why are some monsters gold?
By Cannon Sam on Monday, October 22, 2007 - 12:43 pm:

I've entered a few tournaments where I find a monster colored pure gold. They're not specials, not bred with anything that would give them this color, they're just colored golden. Does anyone know how and why this happens? *Dreams of golden Joker*

~Cannon

By Thorr on Tuesday, October 23, 2007 - 11:11 am:

Well... I booted the game up to see what the heck you were talking about and found my save game is gone.. Looks like my game will no longer save. :(

In all honesty, I don't remember anything special about the monsters you are talking about. I know that they are not available for raising.

By Thorr on Tuesday, October 23, 2007 - 11:14 am:

I booted up my MRA1 game to see if it survived, and it still runs. My Gespenst is still there in town.

It makes me think that the MRA2 battery system is pretty fragile. I was not one to use the Never Tired raising method, so I didn't kill it that way. Oh well..

By Cannon Sam on Tuesday, October 23, 2007 - 01:39 pm:

Ah, sorry to hear that, seeing all the hard work you put into this
game, and I really appreciate it. But hey, you can get a fresh
start. I myself bought a copy of the game for fourteen bucks off
eBay. Thanks again for all the hard work you (along with
GoldenBoy) put into this.

Anyway, the golden monsters. Yeah, they're just pure gold. I've
run into a Momo, a Tiger, and a Hare like this. My friend who
also has the game claims he saw a golden Golem. He also claims
to have seen the Momo. A thing to note is that these are
absoluely no stronger than any other monsters I've seen.

By Infernus on Tuesday, October 23, 2007 - 01:48 pm:

I've never seen a "golden" monster in MRA2 before. In all honesty, I do think you're looking at a case where the monsters are bred with something to give them that colour, in particular, a Suezo or Mew. They're yellow, but under some light, a few of the monsters that combine with them appear sort of gold.

I just checked - my MRA2 battery has always worked fine. That being said, I think you may have played yours more, Thorr, so I guess we'll see how much longer mine lasts...

By Infernus on Tuesday, October 23, 2007 - 01:51 pm:

Double post in light of the fact that your most recent post wasn't there when I wrote my reply:

A Suezo or Mew obviously cannot account for something like a golden Tiger, and none of the ones in the book look golden at all to me.

"Weird" is all I have left to say.

By Cannon Sam on Tuesday, October 23, 2007 - 06:34 pm:

neither the time nor the Gold Bar to experiment with this.
Anyone willing to try?

~Cannon

Monster Rancher Metropolis: Office Of The Mayor: Read This Section First!: Welcome!

20) Peer review does not mean that we will do all the research for unfounded claims. We expect people with "great new discoveries" to have done research which proves their point. The peer review process simply attempts to duplicate prior test results. We do not provide free labor to test out ideas. If you want the fame for a discovery, you are expected to do the work proving it.

By peri on Wednesday, July 23, 2008 - 08:45 pm:

I'll test this out. I think i have a gold bar sitting around accumulating dust so i'll try it with the four suggested monsters(Momo, Tiger, Hare and Golem)to see what happens.

By peri on Thursday, July 24, 2008 - 06:56 pm:

Tested this out a little while ago. The gold bar does nothing when used in combining. As previously suggested it seems likely that these were simply monsters combined with yellow sub-breeds. The only problem with this theory is, as Infernus said, there are no yellow tigers in the game.

I am not saying that golden monsters don't exist; just that it seems unlikely they are created through combining with a gold bar (unless it is like some of the Legends that require specific combinations for the desired result).

Personally I've never seen a "gold' monster so I see no reason to continue testing all possibilities, but I am quite curious to see if this is true.
